They note that Jack Marshall has no alibi for the night of Danny's death and had the boy's cell phone in his possession. Hardy also says that Mark Latimer is still a suspect since he lied to them about his whereabouts and that there's still two hours missing from his alibi. He also mentions that Mark hit Danny according to Tom Miller's statement. When asked whether Mark could have done it, Ellie answers that she doesn't know. Hardy also says that Paul Coates should be a suspect since he has no alibi and his church has a view of the Latimer house. He's running a background check on him but their supervisor tells him to be careful and not risk offending the church.

Paul Coates meets with Becca Fisher and reviews her financial documents. He notes that she's had less income than she had projected and that the bank is demanding repayment of a loan. Beth storms in and begins tearing apart Becca's pub room, smashing glasses, turning on the beer taps, throwing crisps around. She berates Becca for sleeping with her husband and warns her to stay away from her family. Paul ushers her out.

Karen calls her boss, angry that he edited her article in order to make Jack Marshall look more guilty than she had intended. He tells her that he simply punched up the article enough for her to land on the front page and that she should dig more into Jack Marshall's background.

Jack meets with Hardy, who advises him to cooperate with their investigation so that they can clear his name. Jack scoffs that he's heard that before and it ended up with him being charged with a crime. Hardy asserts that the only thing they care about is Danny's death.

Chloe meets with her boyfriend. He tells her that Jack Marshall had kicked him out of the Sea Brigade because Marshall had always liked to hug the boys and he had refused. Chloe texts a Karen and the two kiss. Unseen by them, Mark observes them from afar.

Chloe and Dean go to the Echo and meet with Karen and Olly. Dean gives them a list of other boys who were in Sea Brigade when he was. She advises them to go to the police with this information as well.

Beth and Paul talk. She apologizes for wrecking Becca's pub in front of him but says it felt good. Paul suggests that she see a bereavement counselor, but she refuses, saying that her anger is all she has right now. She tells Paul that Mark thinks she should keep the baby and Paul agrees. She says she hates it and refers to the pregnancy as "a thing which is growing inside me." She says that Danny should be growing and she wasn't done with him yet. She says she failed as a mother since she didn't keep Danny safe and asks why God would create Danny and then take him back. Paul suggests that some think God takes those he loves most sooner and Beth calls God selfish. Beth asks why she's being punished.

Tom Miller plays games at an arcade. When he runs out of money he goes to leave and stops to pet Susan Wright's dog. Susan invites Tom to come by her place any time and walk the dog.

Jack Marshall sits in his shop as photographers crowd outside taking pictures. He calls in Hardy and Ellie and demands police protection but Ellie says that since he hasn't been threatened they can't provide any. Hardy presses Jack Marshall about the details he's kept back. Jack says that he had been a music teacher and that he had "a relationship" with a female student. He claims that the attraction was mutual but her father reported them and he served a year in prison. He says that the girl was 15 years and 11 months old and that if she were a month older he would have escaped any legal consequences. When Ellie asks whether he had any contact with the girl since he says that he married her after his release from prison when she was 17 and he was 40.

Paul Coates approaches Ellie and Hardy and asks for them to help Jack Marshall insisting that he's an "innocent and scared man" who is being wrongfully hounded. Hardy tells him that his concern is noted and walks off. Hardy insists to Ellie that Marshall should still be a suspect and that they cannot be distracted by the press. They meet with their head of forensics. He tells them that they found four cigarette butts near Danny's body and that since they weren't washed away by the tide they had to have been left there around the time the body was deposited on the beach. He says that the cigarettes were from a rare high tar brand that someone might remember having sold recently. Hardy says that it doesn't make sense that the killer would drop off a body and then stand and smoke four cigarettes.

Nige comes by Susan Wright's trailer and gives her a package with 500 pounds in it. She says "that's all I'm worth" and Nige threatens to get his crossbow. She tells him they need to find a way to "work this out... together."

Mark confronts Chloe about her boyfriend and asks how old he is. She says he's seventeen, which makes them the same age as Mark and Beth when they were together. Mark asks if they're having sex and she says yes. She also says that they're using condoms which is more than Mark and Beth did. She yells at him for flirting with Becca Fisher right in front of her when she was working at the hotel. Their argument is interrupted by the doorbell. It's Tom Miller who tells Mark that the other dads are forming a posse to get Jack Marshall.

A bunch of angry men arrive at the Sea Brigade hall. Mark shows up and tells them to back off. He goes and talks to Jack who explains that he had an affair with a teenage girl and that they later married and had a son. Mark asks where his son is now. Jack says that his son was killed at age six in a car accident while he wife was driving. The grief over their loss tore them apart. He says that his interest in the boys and his giving them hugs wasn't sexual, but motivated by his missing his son. He says that he would never harm Danny and that he and Mark are "the same" noting that no parent should outlive their child. Mark angrily tells the mob of men to go home and then advises Jack that it's not safe and he should leave.

Olly takes Karen down to the beach where his boat is kept. He explains that his father used to take him out on it all the time when he was a kid but after his dad left he hasn't taken it out. The boat is kept tied up on the beach with some others. When they get there, however, the boat is gone.

At night Jack Marshall awakes to noise outside his house. When he goes out he discovers that someone has smashed his car window and spray painted "paedo" on one of his boats.

Olly goes to Ellie with the information about the boat. He says the last time he saw it was eight weeks ago. He also asks that if it is the boat which burned then she give him the story. She ignores him and walks out. Brian, the forensics technician confirms to her that the wreckage of the burned boat matches Olly's. Then Brian asks her out for a drink. She tells him she's married. She explains to Hardy that the boat had belonged to her brother-in-law who left her sister several years ago. Hardy asks who knew that the boat was there and she says everybody did. Hardy wonders if Danny knew about the boat. She asks Hardy if they're going to catch the killers and notes that he didn't do so in Sandbrook. He tells her that Sandbrook is different but she presses him on what went wrong. He says that a mistake was made, a big mistake. When she asks him whether it was made by him he says he doesn't want to talk about it and promises that they won't let the town down.

As they ready to go to bed Mark tells Beth that he loves her. She says that he's said that a lot since he got caught, and asks if Danny knew about him and Becca. Mark says no. Mark asks Beth that just for that night they have no bickering and no silences and find something else to talk about.

Becca Fisher comes to Alec's rooms and tells him that she has a lot of reporters asking for rooms. She knows he doesn't want to bump into them in the hallways but she needs the business. She offers him a half off rate for allowing the journalists to stay there. Hardy commiserates with her about how hard it is running the hotel and then asks if she'd like to spend the night. She turns him down saying that she'd be worried he might collapse.

Beth and Mark go through Danny's things and reminisce about their son. At the same time, Jack Marshall gets a delivery of newspapers, all of which carry headlines about him and his past, one reading "Child Bride of Broadchurch Jack". It carries a photo of Jack with his wife and son and when he sees it he breaks down weeping. The next morning, Hardy and Ellie are called to the beach where they find Jack's dead body.

description: The town of Broadchurch comes together to mourn. In doing so, a new suspect in the murder of Danny Latimer comes to light.
tags: ['funeral', 'alcoholic', 'trailer home', 'skateboard']
synopsis_with_character_names:
Alec Hardy walks along the beach at Broadchurch. He sees Steven Connelly, Paul Coates, Nigel, and Mark Latimer standing near the surf watching him. He yells at them to get away from the water. They ignore his cries. He wakes up yelling and takes some pills.

In the police station Hardy looks at a paper whose headline describes him as "The Worst Cop in Britain." He tells Ellie that their Supervisor will be scaling back the manpower on the Latimer case soon. They prepare to go to Jack Marshall's funeral. Hardy tells Ellie that the killer might be there and that they should watch for anything unusual. He tells her that he tailed Paul Coates the other night and found him going to an AA meeting. He asks her to look into him.

The Latimer's prepare for the funeral. Mark tells Beth that he's thinking of going back to work soon and asks her when they're going to talk about the baby. She puts him off.

At the newspaper Olly gets ready for the funeral when Karen arrives. He tells her he felt insulted that she didn't call or try to contact him but just left town. She says that she felt guilty after Jack committed suicide and went to stay with a friend before returning to work. Maggie shows up and berates Kate for contributing to Jack's death but Kate blames the town for turning on him so quickly.

At the funeral, Paul Coates delivers an angry eulogy noting that the town failed Jack and also failed Danny. Afterwards, the community heads to the Trader's for a wake. Ellie and Hardy keep watch to see who is acting strangely. Ellie notes Nigely laughing with some men. Maggie asks Ellie about whether she found anything on Susan Wright and Ellie says she's too busy to really look into it. Alec almost collapses in the middle of the wake, an action that others put off as too much drinking. He steadies himself and goes to question Tom about Paul Coates. Joe intervenes before he can question him too much though. Later, Tom is sitting, playing a video game when Chloe tries to slip out with Dean. She asks him to tell anyone who asks that she's in the loo. When she refers to the fact that he was Danny's best friend, Tom angrily denies it. He says he hated Danny.

Beth meets with Karen who explains that she's not writing about the case anymore and that there likely won't be any more news coverage until the killer is caught. Beth asks Karen if she can introduce her to some of the families from the Sandrbook killings so that she can talk with someone about what she's going through. Karen agrees to try.

Hardy and Ellie question Olly who tells them that anyone could have taken his boat. He says that the last time he used it was about six months before when he took Danny and Tommy paintballing. Ellie expresses surprise and Olly says that Tom asked Joe if he could go because he knew she would say no. He says that lots of people paid his mom to rent the boat, including Paul Coats.

Ellie and Hardy question Paul, who says that he took the boat out for a fishing trip about a year ago. Hardy questions him about his alcoholism and Coates angrily insists that has nothing to do with the case. Hardy insists that he should come in and give a DNA sample.

Mark goes back to work and finds it hard to deal with the solicitousness of Nigel and his clients. Chloe returns to school but finds that everyone is staring at her and has a hard time concentrating in class. Beth goes running and then meets with one of the mothers from Sandbrook. The woman tells her not to trust Hardy, that he messed up the Sandbrook murders: lost evidence, "bollocksed up" the trial and let the murderer go free. The conversation does little to comfort Beth as the woman tells her that her own marriage fell apart as many do after the murder of a child and that she fills up her day with crying, drinking, and sleeping pills. Afterwards, Beth gets a call that Chloe left school. Mark picks her up and drives her to the farm outside town where Dean lives. There they find Chloe listening to music with Dean and dancing. She says that she couldn't take everyone staring at her and that she feels suffocated by being "the dead boy's sister." Dean built her a "happy room" where she can go to just enjoy herself and forget about losing Danny.

Paul is in the police station giving a DNA sample to Hardy. He asks why Hardy seems to have something against him and Hardy accuses Paul of trying to insert himself into this crisis in order to aggrandize the Church. Paul says that people came to him looking for hope because Hardy and the police were not able to provide it. Later, Hardy leaves a phone message for his daughter, telling her that he thinks about her all the time and wondering if they might speak soon.

Maggie calls a friend of hers at another paper to dig deeper into Susan Wright, figuring that they will have to do so themselves since the police won't do anything. He soon faxes her a file full of information. Maggie goes and leaves the file on the door of Susan Wright's trailer.

Tom asks Paul Coates if there's any way to retrieve information which has been deleted from a computer. Paul tells him that it can be done by a technician or with retrieval programs. Later, Tom is standing on the beach when he's approached by Susan Wright and her dog. He plays with the dog as Susan talks to him. She warns him that it's dangerous for him to be alone near the spot where they found the dead boy. Tom tells her that he and Danny used to be friends. She invites Tom back to her trailer to feed her dog. While there she shows him Danny's skateboard and tells him that he can have it since he was Danny's friend.

Mark takes his family to the arcade, insisting that they should play some games and have fun. They play air hockey and grabbers and enjoy themselves. Later, they have some food and reminisce about happier times. Chloe says that they should take the baby to the arcade when it's born.

Tom takes the skateboard home and shows it to his parents. Ellie tells him to put it down and not touch and asks him where he got it. The police arrive in force at Susan Wright's trailer, She's not there so they bust in. Susan is instead at the offices of the Echo where Maggie shows her copies of headlines proclaiming "murder". She says that she knows all about her husband and children and the crimes which she was accused, but never proven, to have committed. She says that Susan threatened her and so she wants Susan to know that it was her who turned Susan in to the cops. Ellie and Hardy stand behind Susan to arrest her. Outside the Echo, Nigel finds Susan's dog tied to a post and takes him away. The only emotion Susan shows is when she's being lead away and sees that her dog is missing.

At the police station, Hardy and Ellie interrogate Susan, but she doesn't tell them anything. She says she won't talk until she sees her dog. Hardy leaves her to sit in a cell and think and tells Ellie to find the dog.

That night, Nigel drives Susan's dog to a secluded spot and aims his crossbow at it. The same night, Paul Coates finds Tom outside smashing a computer with a rock.

At the police station, Ellie gets a call that someone saw a torch being used inside the hut where Danny was killed. She and Hardy race over there. A figure bursts through the cabin door and they give chase. They follow the figure into a boatyard, unable to see who it is. As they search through the drydocked boats, Ellie's mobile rings and the person rushes by, knocking her down. They chase after him but Hardy collapses in pain. Ellie tends to him as the figure runs off. The other police arrive just then and Ellie tells them to go after the fugitive and call and ambulance.

description: Hardy knows his time is running out to solve Danny's murder - will the discovery of a vital clue finally unlock the case?
tags: ['estranged mother', 'crossbow', 'cardiac arrhythmia', 'dog']
synopsis_with_character_names:
Alec has flashbacks to a young boy on a beach and a young girl. He awakes in a hospital bed after having a heart arrhythmia during the chase. Ellie is there. She tells him that the doctors told her about his condition and how he'd had a previous attack and check himself out against medical advice. He tells her he's been six for about a year and a half and it has gotten worse in the last couple of months. She asks why he took the job knowing he was too sick. He tells her that they're close to finding the killer and asks her to not tell their supervisor. Ellie walks out.

Ellie briefs their team, telling them to go through everyone without an alibi or with a weak alibi and to find her dog, Vince. Against medical advice, Hardy checks himself out of hospital and heads back to work. His supervisor informs him that she will be sending him to see the medical officer tomorrow and that he will most likely be relieved of duty. She also asks why he took the job if he knew he was that ill/

Ellie questions Susan Wright. She says that in addition to the skateboard, they found cigarettes matching Susan's brand in the sand around Danny's body. At first, Susan denies knowing anything. Ellie threatens to charge her and have her dog put to sleep when found. Reluctantly, Susan says that she was out walking her dog the night of Danny's murder when she saw the body from the cliff top. She made her way down to the beach and looked at Danny's body. Ellie finds it odd that Susan would stand over a dead boy's body and smoke cigarettes and then not tell anyone. Susan says that Danny was "beautiful" and that she knew his body would be found but that she didn't want to get involved.

Ellie pressures Susan to talk about her previous run in with the law. Susan says that they had two daughters. Her husband was molesting the older daughter. When he tried to do the same to the younger daughter the older one intervened and he killed her. She claims she didn't know about the abuse until afterwards. When her husband was arrested he accused her of knowing. At the time, Susan was pregnant and social services took the baby from her, finding her to be an unfit mother.

At the Echo, Maggie hears from a source about Hardy's medical problems. She gives Olly the chance to ask Hardy about it. Meanwhile, Hardy meets with Steve Connolly, desperate for any lead. Connolly tells him that Danny knew the killer and that it was someone "close to home." Connolly reminds Hardy that he told him "She forgives you about the pendant" and he can tell that this means something to him. He also tells him that he saw that Hardy had been here before. Afterwards, Olly meets with Hardy to offer him the chance to explain his situation to them.

Beth and Mark meet with Paul Coates for some counseling. She says that they're due for a scan with the new baby but she's not sure if she wants to go through with it. She says that her heart is still full of grief for Danny and that she wishes she had been taken instead. Mark remembers the beautiful, happy girl Beth was when they first met and how Danny's murder has changed this. He says that he wonders if Beth wouldn't have been better off not meeting him. Reverend Coates advises Beth to go get the ultrasound and then make her decision. The Latimer's go to the doctor's and seem happy afterwards.

Ellie continues to interrogate Susan, saying that there's no way she could have seen Danny's body from the cliff tops. Under pressure, Susan admits to having been walking on the beach. She says she saw a boat, a small one with an outboard motor. A man pulled up to the beach and laid Danny's body there before leaving. She also says she recognized the man.

The police bring Nigel in for questioning in Danny's murder. They find Susan Wright's dog chained up in his garden and a gun closet with rifles and his crossbow. Nigel calls Mark and tells him about his arrest and that it's all wrong. Mark advises him to just tell the truth.

Hardy interrogates Nigel. At first he claims not to know Susan Wright, but when Hardy tells him that they found her dog in his garden he admits to knowing her. At the same time, Ellie is interrogating Susan. Susan says that Nigel came to her trailer and threatened her with his crossbow because he "didn't like what I was saying" but she claims to forget what she said to have angered Nigel. Hardy pressures Nigel about Danny's murder. He says he wasn't involved in it. Hardy pressures him as to why she would accuse Nigel of dumping the body and Nigel says that it's because she's his mother.

Susan says that Nigel is the son who was taken from her 25 years ago. Recently the law had changed and she was able to try and make contact but that when she did he wanted nothing to do with her. Susan says that she told the police that Nigel did it because he's his father's son and she can't "let it happen again."

Pressed for an alibi, Nigel says that the night of the murder he had driven out to a local estate where he was poaching pheasants. He had run out of petrol and siphoned some from a tractor and then cut a hole in the fence to make it look like a break in. Hardy gives Nigel a file containing newspaper clippings about Susan's family and her husband's arrest. Nigel reads them and weeps.

Ellie yells at Hardy for giving Nigel the file when she had promised Susan that they wouldn't tell him. He tells her that the phone which gave them the tip about the break in at the cabin was made from Danny's missing mobile phone. They wonder why the killer would call in a tip and then try to escape. He tells Ellie that he's going to have Susan and Nigel released and kept under surveillance in the hope that something will happen. Just then he gets a phone call and leaves.

Hardy meets with Paul Coates who gives him Tom Miller's smashed laptop. Coates says he was out walking his regular route when he found the boy trying to destroy it. When Hardy asks why Tom would be trying to destroy his best mate's computer Coates asks if they were best friends. He says that a couple of months ago he had to break up a serious fight between the two boys. He says he had informed both sets of parents and had thought that Ellie would have told him. He also says that Tom threatened to accuse him of abusing Danny if he gave the computer to the police, but denies having done anything inappropriate. When Hardy asks about what he said to Tom at the wake, Coates says he was just trying to comfort the boy. Alec takes the computer and calls a friend to try and get any information off of it.

Hardy meets with Olly and Maggie. He tells them that he was injured pursuing a suspect and asks them not to publish this for a few days. Maggie agrees but asks him to tell them about Sandbrook. He tells them that the case against their suspect had been circumstantial until they found a pendant which belonged to one of the victims in a car the suspect owned. One of his Detective Sergeants was taking the evidence back to the police station when she stopped at a hotel for a drink. While inside her car was broken into and her belongings, including the evidence, was stolen. He says that she was having an affair with another DS and had stopped to celebrate. When Maggie points out that the Herald had reported that it was his car which was broken into he says that he took the heat for her because she was his wife and he didn't want their daughter knowing about the affair. He tells them that if they publish they should tells the family in the Sandbrook case first and let them know that the case isn't closed.

Susan Wright returns home and finds Nigel sitting in her trailer. He tells her that if she doesn't leave within the hour he will kill her dog. She says that if she leaves she will disappear forever and they will never see each other again. He tells her to recant her statement to the police and then leave town. She tells him that he has his father in him and that he was the one she saw.

Dean eats dinner with Chloe and her parents. He gives Beth a gift as thanks for letting him into their family. It's a doll for the new baby. The gift doesn't go over well with Beth and mark confesses that it's "all a bit muddled." To change the topic, Chloe asks about Nigel and Mark says he's had no news. She says it can't be Nigel. Dean agrees, saying that Nige and Danny really got on well and that he saw it every time they went out. The family is puzzled by this and Dean explains that Nigel would come by the farm with Danny and that they three of them would go hunting in the evenings. He says that Danny had assured him it was okay and that Nigel said that they had known. Mark says that they didn't.

Hardy tells Miller that the boot prints found at the hut were a man's size ten. Ellie checks and sees that Nigel's shoe size is a ten. They wonder if Susan Wright had told them the truth about Nigel. Hardy says that they're missing something and suggests that someone else may have been involved. Before sending Ellie home, Hardy asks her about how Tom and Danny were getting along. Ellie denies having heard about the fight which Paul Coates mentioned. Hardy asks if she can give him a look at her son's laptop and she agrees, annoyed.

Susan Wright, surveys her trailer and then begins to leave town. Meanwhile, Ellie searches in vain for her son's computer before going to bed. Still at the police station, Hardy receives an email from his friend with the subject line "Tom Miller email transcripts". After perusing the transcripts Hardy says "Of course!"

Hardy interrogates Nigel. At first Nigel denies knowing Susan Wright.

description: Shock, rather than relief, takes hold of Broadchurch as Hardy finally discovers who murdered Danny Latimer.
tags: ['child strangling', 'strangulation', 'flashback', 'cell phone trace']
synopsis_with_character_names:
Alec Hardy sits on the beach looking out to sea. He remembers sitting on the same beach as a child with a girl. He goes to his department mandated medical exam and is informed by his supervisor that he will have to clear out his office by the end of the day. He says he thinks he knows who the killer is, but walks away.

Joe Miller searches Tom's room for his laptop. Tom comes in and objects and Joe asks about the laptop. Tom says he lost it about a week back. Joe tells him not to lie.

Ellie meets with her sister and gives her the money she asked for. Her sister tells her that the night of Danny's murder she saw a man in dark clothing disposing of a bag of clothes in a garbage bin. At the police station, Ellie tells Hardy about the new information and that Tom claims that he lost his laptop. She says she doesn't believe her son and Hardy says he called Tom and Joe in to be interviewed. When Ellie tells him that the police have lost both Susan Wright and Nigel he angrily tells her to find them.

Nigel lays in his van calls his mother. He leaves a message telling her not to believe the things she's going to hear about him. Before he can do anything he hears police sirens.

Tom is being interviewed by Hardy, with Joe present. Tom says he left his laptop in a bag at school and it got stolen. Hardy tells him not to lie and produces the damaged laptop which Paul Coates gave him. He also produces a transcript of the emails which were gotten from the email server. Hardy says that Danny was using a different email address than the one on his computer. He used this account only to talk to Tom and one other person. Tom says that he thinks Danny sent the emails from his smartphone and that Danny had claimed to have gotten the phone by saving up money from his paper route. Hardy asks why Danny's emails ask Tom to stay away and that they're not friends. Tom says that Danny had found a new friend, one who understood him better. When Hardy brings up a series of emails in which Tom uses threatening language towards Danny, Joe ends the interview. As they leave, Hardy asks their shoe sizes. Tom says five and Joe says ten.

Mark speaks with Beth about whether they should clean out Danny's room for the new baby.

Hardy meets with Ellie down on the beach. He says that he had been here before: as a child his family had come there on holiday. He used to sit below the cliffs to escape his parent's bickering. He hadn't remembered that until he had been assigned to Broadchurch. Ellie gets a phone call that Danny's cell phone has been turned on again and that they can track it. Hardy orders her back to the station to interview Nigel. He quickly grabs her phone from her and orders that the coordinates he sent to his phone. As they leave, he praises her on the good work she's done on the case.

Using his mobile phone, Hardy tracks the cell phone signal to the neighborhood by the Latimer house. Mark Latimer and Paul Coates both see him as he walks across the lawn. He enters a house and sees Tom sitting watching cartoons. Following the signal out back he enters a work shed and finds Joe Miller with the phone. Joe says that he can't stand hiding anymore.

A flashback shows the events the night of Danny's murder. Danny had skateboarded to the cliff top hut. Inside he and Jo sat hugging each other. The hug ends and Danny goes to leave, telling Joe that he won't do this anymore and that he's going to tell his parents. Joe frantically warns Danny that no one will understand and that this will ruin their lives. Danny runs from the hut. He cuts his hand on a piece of fencing and runs towards the cliff. Joe warns him to be careful and asks the boy to come back to the hut. When they get back inside, he locks the door. Danny asks why he did that, and Joe says that he'll let Danny leave if the boy promises not to tell anyone. Danny says he knows what Joe wants from him but that Joe is too afraid to ask. He also asks why Joe never did these things with Tom. When he tries to push past Joe, Joe becomes enraged and pushes Danny up against the wall, saying "I'm not that man." Holding Danny by the neck, he says that he never touched either boy and never would. He says that Danny can't say those kinds of things and that Joe helped him.

When Joe realizes that Danny is dead, he panics. He runs to his car and puts plastic booties on his shoes. He carries Danny's body from the hut and puts it in the boat. Then he cleans off Danny's hands and feet. He dumps the body, and Danny's skateboard on the beach, running off just as Susan Wright comes down the beach. Returning to the hut he is briefly startled when he hears a car approaching. Looking through a window, he sees Mark Latimer and Becca Fisher returning from their tryst. When the two leave, Joe frantically begins cleaning the hut. He dumps something in a trash bin where he is seen by Ellie's sister. Returning home, he frantically scrubs his own body. Then he stands over Tom's bed and silently weeps, before going to sleep beside Ellie.

In the interrogation room, Joe tells Hardy that he was in love with Danny. About nine months ago, Danny had come by their house after Mark had hit him. Joe helped clean Danny up and comfort him. After that, Danny would talk with Joe when he'd come around to play with Tom. Danny said he couldn't talk to his own father like that and the two began meeting in secret. He says that he wanted something which was his own and would lie to Ellie about where he was. He claims he never touched Danny and that all they'd do would be hug each other, fully clothed. Hardy asks for more details, trying to understand. Joe says that if he can't understand why should Hardy. When asked, Joe admits to giving Danny the mobile phone and five hundred pounds. He said he did it because he needed Danny to love him. Hardy asks why Joe called from the cabin. Joe says that he couldn't take it any more and needed to confess. He felt responsible for Jack Marshall's death too. He had hoped that only Hardy would come, in order to spare Ellie. But when he saw his wife, he panicked and ran.

Hardy goes into the other interview room, where Ellie is interrogating Nigel. He abruptly stops the interrogation and orders everyone else out of the room. He tells Ellie that the killer is not Nigel and asks her where she was the night of Danny's death. She asks if she's a suspect and he says he'll explain but that he needs her to just answer his questions. She says that they had just gotten back from a vacation in Florida and that she had taken a sleeping pill in order to overcome her jet lag. When asked, she says that she doesn't remember Joe coming to bed. Hardy crosses to her side of the table and tells her that Joe killed Danny Latimer. Ellie insists that Joe didn't do it. She begins to cry and runs into a corner to dry heave. She says that both Susan Wright and her sister saw Nigel. Hardy explains that they mistook Joe, who has a similar build to Nigel and is also bald, for Nigel. She insists that Hardy is wrong but he tells her he's not. She then asks to see Joe.

Hardy warns her not to touch Joe or do anything which might jeopardize a conviction. She enters the interview room and Joe tries to go to her. She tells him to sit down and asks if it's true. Joe insists that he never touched their sons or Danny and says that he always loved her. She screams at him that Danny was eleven and when Joe asks about Tom, she attacks him. The other officers pull her off.

Afterwards, Hardy tells Ellie that they've booked her family a room at a nearby hotel and that she shouldn't answer the phone for anyone who isn't him. She goes by the house to pick up her things and the forensics team are already there. SOCO tech Brian Young tells her he'll have to accompany her around the house. As she leaves she notes that her family was happy here.

Hardy calls Karen Young, who upbraids him for giving Olly the story about Sandbrook. He tells her that they've caught Danny's killer and that he's giving her exclusive advanced warning of the announcement. Hardy then talks to the other officers and says that there is no evidence that Ellie knew about Joe's crime or did anything improper. He says that she'll need all their help.

He then goes to the Latimer house where he gathers the family and tells them that they've charged Danny's killer. When he tells them that it's Joe, they're disbelieving and ask if he's sure. He tells them about the meetings Danny and Joe had and that Ellie didn't know. Mark rushes out of the house. At the hotel, Ellie tells Tom that Joe was the one who killed Danny and that she can't explain it.

As Hardy makes the announcement of the arrest, Olly's mom shows up at the Echo and asks him to come with her. A montage shows the Latimer family reacting to the news. Mark rages at a beach. Chloe goes to the crime scene at the Miller house. Beth stands stunned in their house.

Mark goes to the police station, where one of the officers lets him have five minutes to speak to Joe in his cell. He asks how Joe could have done it, having been their friend. Joe apologizes and says it was an accident. He says that Danny only came to him because Mark wasn't a fit father and abused Danny. Mark screams at Joe not to use that as an excuse. He says it was only one time and now he'll be haunted by it for the rest of his life. Mark also says that Joe must have "done stuff" to Danny, despite his denials. Joe says that all he ever did was care for Danny. Mark says that he can't even bring himself to hate Joe. Instead he pities him, because Joe is "nothing."

Olly and his mom arrive at the hotel to watch the kids and give Ellie a break. She says she's going for a walk. Outside the hotel she meets Karen White, who offers her condolences and advises her not to talk to anyone. Ellie ends up on the lawn behind her house and the Latimer house. Beth Latimer comes out and asks her "how could you not know?" Ellie then goes to Hardy's hotel room to talk. She asks how a grown man could be in love with an eleven year old boy and wonders if he's a paedophile. She notes that there were no signs of abuse on Danny and that Tom says that Joe never did anything improper with him. Hardy says that he doesn't have the answers and insists that people are unknowable and that "you can never really know what's in someone's heart." He tells her that he began to suspect Joe two days ago when he got the email transcripts of Danny's account which only communicted with two people: Tom and Joe. He also tells Ellie that he really hoped he would be wrong.

The Latimers have Danny's funeral at long last. At the service, Paul Coates speaks of the bible telling them to put away all malice, be kind to each other, and forgive each other as Christ forgave. He admits that after what they've been through, doing so may be difficult but that they have a responsibility to themselves and to God to try.

Ellie and Hardy sit near the beach and discuss their futures. Ellie says that she'll be leaving town to give the kids a fresh start. Hardy says that it's all over for him since he'll be receiving a medical discharge. Ellie dubs them the "ex detectives club."

The Latimer's go to a bonfire on the cliff while the townspeople go to one on the beach. They light the two simultaneously and as they watch other bonfires are lit along the coast. Paul Coates says he spread the word. As they watch the fire, Beth has a vision of Danny standing nearby. The Latimer family and Dean stand together and watch the lights along the coast.

description: An ex-con bears a grudge against the city of Los Angeles. He wants to blow up city hall unless his demands are met. He has a powerful bomb. The police find 28 sticks of dynamite in his apartment. Only Sergeant Friday has the power to stop this 1950s terrorist attack.
synopsis_with_character_names:
Synopsis - The Human Bomb Airing 12-16-51 Sergeants Friday and Romero are working the early watch out of Central Division, Detective Bureau, Friday gets an emergency call to return to HQ, a threat to destroy the building by a distraught individual has put the entire city block in peril. Friday narrates they have less than a half-hour to stop this man from blowing up the building; this is the story of those twenty-six minutes.

Early watch out of Central Homicide is what Sergeants Friday and Romero had been working, the boss is Thad Brown, Chief of Detectives. Friday enters the building, it is city hall, police station-jail included. The elevator operator calls out his name, flags him down, telling him they have to take this car, it is the only one in service. He brings him to the floor where his partner, Sgt. Romero, and Chief Brown meet him.

Brown tells the Sergeants, fifty-five minutes ago, a man walked in here with a home-made bomb under his arm, threatening to set it off unless his brother was released from jail by nine o'clock this morning. Friday looks at the man's police jacket. He has a been in and out jail for the last five years, name is Vernon Carney; his brother, Elwood Carney, is serving a year for car-stripping.

A time check off of Friday's watch is 8:34. Chief Brown asks if they are in on this case, simply a volunteer decision. A single man, Friday, chooses to handle the totally voluntary case. Romero has a family, says Friday, as Joe volunteers for the assignment. Romero says he can't go home, his wife wants him to paint the bathroom today. Romero stays. Chief Brown's instructions are simple, there's a man with a bomb in the next room, take it away from him. The Chief goes to check if everyone else is out of the building, he will be back in a minute, warning the men, Carney knows what he is doing, he is no pushover.

Friday narrates the two big questions: was Vernon Carney holding a real bomb or a harmless gadget; was Carney willing to set the bomb off by nine if his demand was not met. One thing for certain, they had only twenty-four minutes to talk him out of it. Friday looks at his watch, it was eight-thirty-six; both Sergeants enter Carney's location, labeled board room on the door. As they approach, Carney says that is far enough; the ticking sound is the bomb or the clock on the wall. Carney's stare, while seated with the bomb box in his lap, reflects he means business; a very cold stare. Romero tells him we are not going let your brother out of jail. Carney states you have until nine o'clock to change your mind, twenty-two minutes; the camera pans the clock on the wall.

The conversation intensifies among the two police officers and the perpetrator. By now, the Sergeants believe it is a real bomb Carney now has on the table, with his hand on the bomb mechanism. The clock showed nineteen minutes to go as the men leave to room joining the Chief in another area. Brown takes a call, the men listen, they found twenty-eight sticks of dynamite in Carney's apartment. Eighteen minutes before nine, the tension mounts for an answer. The screen goes to black.

Friday says the bomb is real, they can see through the glass window one end of the box. They didn't know if he had the nerve to pull the trigger, if it would go off if he did, but the sticks in his room at least validated dynamite was in his possession. Friday says his watch showed sixteen-and-a-half minutes to nine. The Sergeants and Chief talk in an adjacent room. Friday has an idea for someone to slug Carney entering from the outside window, the bomb squad could help with disarming the bomb afterward. They open their window to look at the ledge, eighteen inches wide, a strong wind could have the person torn away from the building, plummeting to certain death. Chief Brown says it is too risky, but with the help from the fire department's ladder, there might be a possibility of an alternative plan.

The dictagraph needs to be activated without Carney seeing the set-up. Friday heads for Carney's room. They convince Carney the dictagraph is needed for him to talk to his jailed brother, Elwood, there are no operators left in the building. The bomb-box remains in Carney's lap. The officers leave the room to help speed up the meeting between brothers. Carney mentions the receiver of the dictagraph is off the hook; Friday narrates the failure of the ruse. Friday and Romero exit the Carney room.

Sam Erickson, Fire Battalion Chief, Lt. Lee Jones, crime-lab, are in the room with Chief Brown. The new plan is to lower a man on a life line to the window. Somebody enters through the window, knocks Carney taking his hand away from the bomb-trigger. The bomb is placed in a bucket of water, Jones says the man elected will get the bomb out of the building as quickly as he can. Romero is picked to slug Carney, knocking him out; Friday is grab the bomb, placing it in the water-filled bucket. The Chief is getting Elwood on the phone to talk to his brother Vernon. Friday checked with the elevator operator, making certain the car is ready at their floor, then he dismissed him out of the building.

The Sergeants tell Carney they are getting his brother on the phone. Carney doesn't buy their story, picking up the phone, throwing it through the glass door, ordering the men to get Elwood out of jail. The Chief comes in, sees the broken glass, telling Carney it is his show, outside the Carney room is Chief Erickson, Lt. Jones with the water, set next to their door where Carney sits. Romero is outfitted with the ropes and belt. Chief Erickson says there is a twenty-mile-per-hour wind out there that could effect the plan.

Chief Brown asks Friday if he is scared; Friday says yes, the Chief replies that makes it even. The intention is to keep Carney's attention, while Ben lowers himself to the window, entering and slugging Carney. Friday answers Brown's time check, we got eight minutes left. A call is placed to the jail asking for Elwood Carney to appear. Vernon Carney orders the two to sit, they glance at one another, keeping Carney's attention away from the window behind him. The clock reads four-and-a-half minutes before nine. Romero's shoes makes a noise on the window, Carney notices, ordering the man be pulled back up. Request met, as Elwood enters the room, Carney greets his brother, after he latches the window shut.

Friday is told to get a car waiting for the brothers; Elwood tells Vernon we are going to need a gun when we get out of here. Romero decides to walk the ledge trying to knockout Vernon with his sap. He starts for the ledge, with Friday telling him to go the other window, Carney locked the one behind him. Elwood is going for the Chief's gun, Brown backs away from Elwood, Romero enters, hits Vernon with the sap, Brown slugs Elwood, Friday grabs the bomb, puts it in the bucket of water, runs to the elevator, operates it to the main floor, where he dashes for the door. Lt. Jones yells, down here Friday, he slips on the steps, losing his footing, falling, covering his head with his hands, the bomb falls out from the bucket. The bomb battery fizzles from being immersed. Lt. Jones hold the broken trigger mechanism, saying it would take a good yank to set off the bomb, being rigged for a strong trigger pull. Romero picks up a dynamite stick, one of many in the bomb box, now broken on the steps. Joe remains sprawled on the base of the steps, Brown crouches behind him, noticing the men are alright.

The suspect was examined by five different psychiatrists. They found him to be mentally incompetent. Vernon Carney is now confined in the State Mental Institution for the Criminally Insane. Elwood Carney served the balance of sentence with no time off for good behavior.

description: A trail of stolen narcotics lead Friday and Romero to a TV actor who is addicted to heroin.
synopsis_with_character_names:
Season 1 Episode 2 Synopsis - The Big Actor Airing 1-3-52 Sergeants Friday and Romero working the day-watch out of Narcotics Detail, the boss is Captain Kearney, they are at the Catholic hospital, where its pharmacy was robbed of all narcotics, about $10,000 worth. The concern was the stolen drugs could be spread around the city. Sister Benedict, pharmacy nurse, is interviewed, telling of the injured intern, Lyon. He was on the floor when she opened the pharmacy door that morning. The narcotics safe was emptied; she gives Romero a look at the inventory list of the safe's stolen drugs. Nine stitches to Lyon's head were required, he is resting in the hospital; the officers talk to Lyon, but he was hit from behind, not seeing his assailant. He could add nothing to what was already known. The entire hospital staff was questioned, screened. The narrative Friday provides reiterates the truth about the portioning of the purloined items to all addicts across the area; speed was a necessity in find the drugs based on street sale value.

At HQ, the officers talk to Sgt. Harlan Stall, crime lab-fingerprints, who tells the room and safe were clean of any prints; nothing to find. Captain Kearney enters the room, stating Babe Kellogg, junkie, is in the squad room, able to answer their questions. Lt. Louis Walters, checks the serial numbers against the found prescriptions with Kellogg. Kellogg thinks he is elsewhere, not LA. He is high on the drugs he recently took. Walters calls for the Captain to enter another room where he shows the serial numbers match those stolen earlier, as Friday looks on with Romero staying with Kellogg. The two vials found in Kellogg's car are both morphine. Leonard Castle, actor, sold drugs to Kellogg, who gave him up to police.

Friday checks with central casting, gets a set-location for Castle; he and Romero go the sound-stage where Castle is supposed to be filming. They find Castle. He says he doesn't know Kellogg; never heard of him. In between takes, Castle keeps stumbling over his responses to the inquiry from the Sergeants. He counts the currency in his wallet in plain view of the officers, saying he won some of it playing cards last night, and he got up at 5AM. Friday accuses him of selling Kellogg two vials of morphine for five-hundred. Asking Castle again, where he got the money. He cracks, saying he was sick once, his hospital was the same hospital he robbed, needing the fast money he owed. He confesses to the robbery, the rest of the money is in the car, he sold Babe Kellogg the two vials because he needed the money, as tears roll from his eyes. He was broke.

Ben takes Castle away, Joe listens to director Jack tell Friday Castle told a great story, but in front of the camera he goes to the dogs.

Suspect Leonard Castle was tried, convicted first degree burglary, one-count, violation of the state narcotics act, one-count and is now serving his term in the state penitentiary. Arthur Babe Kellogg was convicted of the state narcotics act, one-count and is now serving his term in the state penitentiary.

description: Detective Sergeant Friday has been assigned to homicide detail. A socially prominent citizen is plotting to kill his wife. He tells a friend the plans of his murder and hires him to do the killing. It's Friday's job to stop him by going undercover and posing as a hired killer.
synopsis_with_character_names:
It looks like we don't have any synopsis for this title yet. Be the first to contribute.
Learn more

description: Twins are born in a hospital, but soon one is kidnapped. The detectives must find the missing baby before it's too late.
synopsis_with_character_names:
Season 1 Episode 4 Synopsis - The Big Mother Aired 1-31-52 Sergeants Friday, Jacobs are working the night-watch out of Homicide, the boss is Captain Lohrman, the call they responded to was Mercy Hospital, the Superintendent of Nurses, made the call. The hospital nursery was left unattended for 90 seconds, in that time, a newly born baby was taken from its crib. How long could a three-day-old-baby survive in the hands of a kidnapper? The police had to find the new-born fast. It was raining, eleven-thirty PM, when the officers met with Doctor Walsh, Chief of Staff Mercy Hospital. Nurse O'Connor, in-charge of the nursery, when the infant went missing, as she went to take a phone call just feet away from the nursery. The missing infant was one of twins, belonging to the Stryker's. The mother had not been informed just yet, and the father was on his way to the hospital.

Steps were taken to notify every conceivable outlet for the missing baby, as Friday called in the status to HQ. It was midnight, a three-day-old-baby was taken from the hospital, for reasons unknown to anyone, but the perpetrator. The officers talk to George Stryker, asking if anyone he knows would do such a thing; promising he would notify the police if anyone contacts him about the baby. Sergeant Joe Olivas, another officer called on duty, asks Sergeants Friday, Jacobs and his partner Gill, to go to the side entrance, one such door was unlocked, or easily opened, because of a faulty lock, as Friday demonstrates. From the open side door, they traced the steps to the nursery. It proved someone would have been able to enter through that side door, go to the nursery, snatch a baby and exit by the same door without being seen by the attending duty-nurse. Shopkeepers along the Stacy Avenue entrance were alerted, no fingerprints were available on the wet door.

Back at the office, at 10AM the next morning, the press had been alerted, calls came in as expected, no leads turned up. Gill and Olivas greet the officers, leaving the squad room, when John Wallace enters the squad room. Wallace introduces himself as the 11th St. Blue Bird Hotel desk clerk. He says a woman checked in the hotel with a baby at midnight, no luggage, The officers go to the hotel with Wallace, knock on the door, no answer, they all enter, she is not in, nor is the baby. Her registered name is Mrs. Parks. Underneath the bed quilt is a blanket from Mercy Hospital, Friday shows Ed Jacobs. The place is checked for fingerprints, nothing. People in adjoining rooms were questioned, they all provided nothing. The hospital validated the blanket belonging to them. Other than registering as Mrs. Parks, there wasn't much to go on; the registration card was checked for handwriting and fingerprints, the Captain issued bulletins on the woman with a description from hotel employees. Three PM Friday, the search continued, Jacobs is on the phone with another dead end. Olivas, partner Gill, were at a drug store for coffee, a woman came in purchasing several baby related items, also asking the druggist if he could heat the formula for her.

A call comes in with neighbors claiming the Salazar's brought a baby home last night, but the blond baby does match Salazar's dark complexion. Sergeants Friday, Jacobs travel to the Salazar's, Friday says this could be like many of the calls they have experienced, or could be legit. They meet Frank Salazar at the door, they are having a baptismal party for his son, the house is full of guests. They go the infant's room, Friday glances at the boy, saying I think he has a twin. Footprints are taken of the baby's feet by Sergeant Harlan Stall, the prints match those of the missing baby. Interviewing Mrs. Salazar, she insists the baby in the other room was just brought on a flight from Phoenix last night. Jacobs, Friday say the hotel clerk can identify you and the druggist who waited on you. The baby's blanket matched, the color coat she wore last night matches; she is told, the baby belongs to a family called Stryker.

Roberta Salazar confesses to the crime, she got pregnant, had the baby in Phoenix, but the doctor later told her the baby had died, no explanation. After years of trying to have a baby, they were so happy she was pregnant, giving birth in Phoenix. After hearing from the doctor the baby had died shortly after his birth, she left the hospital, took the plane home, walked around thinking what to tell Frank. She says she walked past the hospital, went in the side door, when the nurse was gone, she took a baby, going to the hotel, until it stopped raining, then she took the baby home to her husband. Tears run down her cheeks, her husband exits, to tell the guests there has been a mistake. The officers say they think they can get it straightened out. All bow their heads, as the episode closes on a grim note; at the very least, the baby is safe, heading back to its rightful parents.

The subject woman was examined by five court-appointed psychiatrists and found to be under complete mental strain. By recommendation of the court, Roberta Salazar was admitted to the state mental institution, and later removed to a private sanitarium for further treatment.

description: Friday begins to question Henry Ross, a suspect in a man's disappearance, which Friday believes is actually a murder. Ross coolly and calmly denies any involvement in the disappearance, but Friday's relentless interrogation soon begin to crack the man's facade.
tags: ['interrogation', 'serial murder', 'polygraph', 'murder investigation', 'lie detector']
synopsis_with_character_names:
Season 1 Episode 5 Synopsis - The Big Cast Aired 2-14-52 Friday, Jacobs are working the day-watch out of Homicide, the boss is Detective Chief Thad Brown, it was a sultry October day, at 10:45 AM, they arrived at the Ortega Hotel, a thirty-year-old man had disappeared suddenly, evidence was uncovered of foul play. The list of suspects was narrowed to one man, the last person known to see him alive. The officers had traced the suspect for months, finally the break came, they found him. Friday, Jacobs go the man's room, Henry Ross is his name. They identify themselves as police officers, they ask if he is Henry Ross, entering the room, the suspect breaks a chair over Jacobs, attempting to slug it out with Friday. Friday subdues him with punches, Jacobs cuffs him from behind, sits him in a chair. They order Ross to get dressed, they want to talk downtown, he brushes his teeth, while cuffed from the front. They ask about a missing Paul Davis, he responds, I knew a Davis, don't know if his name was Paul. His face is bleeding, as he finishes brushing, Friday wipes blood from his own face. Is something wrong, Ross asks. Friday responds, yeah, murder. After they search Ross's room thoroughly, they take him back to the interrogation room.

Ross was a longshoreman by trade, a heavy drinker, with a violent temper. Friday says Ed and I questioned Ross for a half-an-hour, they got nowhere. Friday explains the missing man's agenda to Ross, Davis' car was sold and he did not sell it. Davis was on his way up to another town to take a new job, but he never made it. That is when they found his car, not him. Davis's signature was forged on the car title. The forgery was signed by Henry Carter. Ross denies ever using an alias. Friday shows Ross the pink slip of the sold car, reading from Davis, seller, to Carter, buyer. Jacobs says the signatures are both in your handwriting. Ross keeps fiddling with a book of matches, denying the signatures are his, never seeing the pink slip before now. Friday claims the police handwriting expert says the signatures are from Henry Ross. Friday shows Ross a letter, which he denies is his handwriting.

The letter was written by Henry Carter to Paul Davis' wife, claiming the car was sold to someone and Carter had to write the letter. Davis has been gone four months, the police thinks he was murdered. Six men have been missing, taking off on auto trips, no trace of them to date; Ross is now tearing up the matchbook he was earlier fidgeting. Jacobs brings Henry's record from Baton Rouge to Friday; Friday reads to Henry. Friday tells Henry on June 4th Paul Davis left in his car, stopping for gas, accompanied by a man described by the station attendant meeting Ross's description. Friday continues to tell the story with two more stops of the car. After which, that is the last time Davis was seen alive, the people identify the man Davis was last seen with was Ross. The dealer buying the car identifies Ross' mug shot as the man selling the car as Henry Carter.

Ross asks Friday, Jacobs if they each think he murdered Davis. Friday and Jacobs say yes, they do think he killed Davis. Ross states there is only one way to prove if he is the murderer, find Davis' body. Mid-day, Friday, Jacobs took Henry Ross out and fed him lunch, then they all returned to the interrogation room. Ross talked about the different cases he read up on, all but talking about Davis. He never asked for an attorney, seemed calm as he talked. They made arrangements for a lie detector test that Ross consented, without hesitation. Sgt. Berger administered the polygraph test, then the three returned to the interrogation room.

Ross kept talking, the officers let him talk, it was eight PM. Ross says he liked reading about murder cases. Berger has the results of the polygraph, sixteen positive reactions to the test. Friday tells Henry, there were sixteen positive responses to the lie-detector test; he lied sixteen times. Ross asks Friday, Jacobs let's get something to eat, bring a map, I will tell you where I buried him.

At Henry's request, Helga's Health Shop was where he wanted to dine for his evening meal. The three sat down at Helga's, each man ordered something to eat; it was near closing time, Henry order the most food. Ross says he could write down the information. He did not know Davis from before, he was hitchhiking, Davis picked him up. He got the idea of killing him when they stopped for gas, and he saw a few bucks in his wallet.

Ross says you don't need any reason to kill somebody, Davis had eighteen bucks in his wallet, that is as good a reason as any. He admits killing Davis outside of Bakersfield, a little canyon there. He picked up a fifth of sherry in Bakersfield, got Davis to drink some of it. They stopped about two miles out of town, both fell asleep in a shack Ross had spotted.

Ross picked up a two-by-four, started to swing at faces he saw, about a dozen people's faces. The faces disappeared after he saw Davis on the floor; after he killed Davis. He says he buried Davis near the shack, burned his clothes and drove off. He admits to killing the other men in other towns, no reason given. Friday asks him about those killings Henry, any more you want to tell us about? Ross answers Friday, he told them already. He mentions one killing where he sold the car in Mexico, saying he wish he had done the same with Davis' car. Jacobs asks when the first killing was; Henry answers, maybe 18 months, two years ago. The first one wasn't any harder than the last. Ross says he was only bothered by the killings just that once, when was dreaming, saw faces, while he was sleeping in the shack with Davis. Ross thanks Friday for the meal.

The suspect was tried and found guilty of murder in the first degree. Henry Ross was executed in the lethal gas chamber of the State Penitentiary, San Quentin, CA.

description: Someone murdered a secretary late at night in her office. She was beaten to death with a metal pipe wrapped in newspaper. Could it be the drunk found three blocks away beating his head against a wall?
tags: ['murder investigation', 'mission', 'fire station', 'brother brother relationship']
synopsis_with_character_names:
Synopsis - The Big September Man - Aired 5-8-52 A secretary is found killed in her office building, beaten with a newspaper-wrapped, steel pipe, left aside her body. A suspect was picked up, half-drunk, and questioned by Joe Friday and Ed Jacobs. Suspect claims he knows the girl, not a romantic relationship, she just lent him money whenever he was short. She gave him a five and he split immediately afterward; he mentioned there was a guy in her office, but he did not get a good look at the guy. He tells Friday he would be unable to identify the other guy if he saw him.

A search of the apartment of suspect Robert French yielded blood stained clothes, where the suspect says is the result of being drunk and falling. They book him, later Sgt. Lopez has verified he is a quiet drunk, never bothers anybody.

Looking up the common factors in the killing of Adele Prior with other recent murders, brings them to look for another man. The other man is identified as William Tanner, the guy in Adele Prior's office when Robert French was there. Tanner was suspected of beating a woman one year prior with a steel pipe.

The police want to question Tanner, but are unable to locate him. They visit his brother at his workplace; he is a fireman. The brother, Martin Tanner, provides insight to Tanner's one-sided relationship with Adele. He liked her, but she did not care either way; Martin says she seemed to be playing the field, when he met her.

The police put an APB out on William Tanner. Police research validates his brother's description of his behavior; religion is part of his life. His whereabouts are unknown, his brother does not have his current address with him, but they find Tanner in a revival hall. The two other detectives on the case check Tanner's apartment, while Joe and Ed continue talking to him.

Tanner confesses to killing Adele while questioned at the revival hall. Bloodstained clothing in his room corroborated the story as Tanner gave a complete confession at HQ. He continued to admit to killing the other woman a year ago in September and planting a bomb that never went off in a hotel on a prior September. The hotel was his former employer that paid him late, which he claims never forgave them.

Tanner gets two convictions for first degree murder and is executed at San Quentin Penitentiary.

description: Friday and Jacobs question a jeweler regarding the robbery of a colleague. The man takes offense at being questioned about the incident, but as the detectives begin to amass evidence, the jeweler's outrage quickly begins to lose credibility.
tags: ['telephone call', 'tape recording', 'jewel thief', 'interrogation', 'husband wife relationship', 'busy signal']
synopsis_with_character_names:
Season 1 Episode 12 Synopsis - The Big Phone Call Aired 5-22-52 Friday, Jacobs are working the day-watch out of Robbery Detail, the boss is Captain Didian, a sultry mid-July in Los Angeles, and Friday narrates about a robbery nine months ago. The victim was a jewelry salesman, assaulted, robbed of $20,000 in precious stones.

It took a considerable time to gather evidence of the person suspected of the crime. The officers bring in Ernest Garvey for questioning. He denies having anything to do with the victim's robbery, claiming he was a friend of the victim, Thomas Ashley. Garvey says it was reported the assault came behind Ashley's business, next to Garvey's business. Ashley's sample case contents was stolen, $20,000 unset diamonds, and Garvey speaks of the crime, but denies anything to do with the case. Jacobs and Friday grill Garvey.

The officers are certain Garvey is their man, they have to get him to talk. The job was engineered by Garvey, he had someone pull the job and the cops know who he is, too. Garvey's spending habits, the major purchases he recent made all point to a change of lifestyle, only supported by the money gained from selling the stolen gems.

Friday, Jacobs feed Garvey with the facts of how the paid-for-robbery went down, based on surveillance they have in the form of tapes from every conversation he has had for months out of his office, including the young man he furnished with a gun to rob Ashely. They play a tape recording of the fence Garvey used to move the gems, and Garvey speaks about the young man pulling the job. The officers are quite clear to Garvey, they merely want a statement. He denied knowing Tyson, the holdup man, but the tape says otherwise. The fence he said he didn't know, but the tape tells a different story; he lied. The recordings are from the old dictographs, set in the walls by the police before Garvey moved into his office; no phone lines were tapped.

Friday plays another tape to jog Garvey's memory. The tape is a conversation of Tyson asking for his remaining $500 balance for pulling the job. Garvey says it is a fake. He calls their bluff. Friday says he bluff is bad, and he is booked in. The questioning continued, Garvey's answers became more confused. He is asked about his new car purchase and his wife's new fur; where did he get the money? He says he borrowed some of it. Records show loans from three banks total in the thousands, but Garvey made around fifteen-hundred. Multiple bank accounts show savings unaccounted for, per his business income statement; the police want to know where the money in the savings accounts came from, when Garvey wants to call his wife. His first try gets a busy signal; he tries again, busy, a third time, busy. Friday tells him about his expenses and they do not jibe with his income, including the loans.

Jacobs plays a tape of Tyson demanding his money after the robbery, while Garvey makes another attempt to call home, but gets a busy signal. He finally admits his wife's demands of improving their household income in order to buy better things became too much. The robbery of the diamonds was to shut her demands up. She spent every bit, he did not have enough to pay Tyson his $500. He asks to be booked in now. A last minute busy signal from home; Friday had said the police will take his statement down the hall, for the record.

Ernest Garvey was tried, convicted for robbery in the first degree and is now serving his term in the State Penitentiary, San Quentin, CA.

description: Friday and Jacobs are called to the apartment of a man who phoned in the fatal shooting of his wife. He claims it was suicide, but upon looking at the crime scene and talking to neighbors they begin to wonder if it was murder.
tags: ['suicide', 'shell casing', 'murder investigation', 'forensic science', 'ballistics']
synopsis_with_character_names:
Season 1 Episode 13 Synopsis - The Big Casing Aired 6-5-52 Friday, Jacobs are working day-watch Homicide Detail, it was Sunday, March 9th, called to the apartment of a man claiming the death of his wife was suicide, evidence indicated murder. Lt. Harry Fremont informs the men what he found so far, being the first officer on the scene. Husband, Andy Robertson, explains he was arguing with his wife, he went to the store, came back, the words continued, she went to the drawer, where the .45 was kept. She said to Andy, this will put an end to the argument once and for all. She then pulled the trigger. Her dead body is shown on the kitchen floor. Robertson went to his wife, saw she shot herself, went to the neighbor to call police, came down to his apartment, waited, sitting on the couch for the police.

Lt. Lee Jones, from the crime lab, enters the apartment, goes right to the body in the kitchen, while Lt. Harry Fremont escorts Robertson to HQ for his statement and further questioning. Lt. Jones notices the steak to be prepared lying in flour on the cutting board, the spent casing is out on the carpeting, not in the expected position with the deceased. George Wright, crime photographer, enters, Friday removes the plate he used to cover the casing on the rug. Wright takes the photos, steps aside. Jones, with Friday holding the tape, measures the distance from the dead woman's feet to the casing in the living room. Friday, Jacobs leave Harry and Lee in the apartment, taking the elevator to the neighbor upstairs.

Friday, Jacobs visit with the neighbor, Ted Carleton, where Andy, not having a phone, went to call the police. Neighbor Ted says the arguments were frequent, speculating Andy probably killed his wife, based on what he has heard over the two years he knew them. Ted continues to talk to the police, indicating he thought the likelihood of Andy pulling the trigger. Friday uses Ted's phone, calling HQ. There is no record on either Robertson. Joe, Ed questioned neighbors, including the apartment manager, the stories agreed concerning the Robertson's; they argued frequently and were quite loud. Nobody in the building ever heard Andy threaten his wife.

The officers went back to the interrogation room to further question Andy Robertson. Andy does not seem to be particularly upset about his wife. He explains over the eight years of marriage, things were not right from the start, but the last two years they drifted apart. He says he could not stop his wife after she grabbed his pistol from the drawer, it happened too fast. It was Sunday, he liked to sleep in on Sundays. He was asked to go to the store; he didn't like that, which started the arguing. He recounts the actions prior to the death of his wife. The story is the same, to the detail. Both officers tell him they think he killed his wife; he denies it. Jacobs tells him the neighbors all vouch for the arguments they heard. The empty casing found in the living room does not figure with the operation of that pistol. The casing should have been on the kitchen floor after it ejected. The flour seen on the cutting board where the wife was about to coat the steak was on the barrel of the gun, not on the butt. A policeman takes Robertson's statement about his wife committing suicide. All evidence is collected, charted, relatives interviewed, fingerprints taken of Andy and his wife.

Lieutenant Jones shows Friday, Jacobs final pictures of the crime scene, including the actual casing and another same casing. The actual casing has a dent, the sample casing does not. The husband said he went to his wife after the shot, he inadvertently stepped on the spent casing, as the Lieutenant demonstrates with a piece of linoleum. More evidence shows a flour sack on top of the wastebasket in the kitchen, indicating the possibility of the gun falling from her hand after the shot, striking the sack on the way to the floor. She wiped her hands on the apron before she got the gun, explaining why no flour on the gun butt. Evidence of the powder burns from her skull, the spent bullet lodged in the cabinet, all indicate she shot herself from close range; not likely the case if she was shot by someone else. A struggle would have likely ensued, not leaving the same powder burns, furthermore the angle from the lodged bullet, considering the woman's height, the evidence points to suicide with the weapon from the drawer.

Friday takes a call from Lieutenant Fremont. Mrs. Robertson's mother had a letter written by her daughter indicating in the past, she spoke about taking her own life. The mother is certain her daughter committed suicide. Friday, Jacobs are headed back across the street to talk to Andy Robertson and Lieutenant Jones wants to be there when they tell him it was suicide; he is innocent, as he told the officers previously.

The coroner's report exonerated Andrew Robertson of any complicity in the death of his wife and he was released from custody.

description: Friday after a safe burglar on the loose.
tags: ['safecracker', 'police', 'los angeles california', 'burglary', 'detectives']
synopsis_with_character_names:
Season 1 Episode 14 Synopsis - The Big Lamp Aired 6-19-52 Friday, Jacobs are in Superior Court, where an ex-con is on trial for burglary of a safe on the third floor of an office building. Evidence is over-whelming pointing the man committing the crime, i.e. his shoe size, shoe make, shoe cleats, debris on his pants from the building, paint on his shoe-soles from the building fixtures, etc. The odds pointing to any other individual other than the ex-con are greater than the population of the earth since time began. Friday expects a quick verdict, instead the jury was locked up for the night, all went home. Next morning, the ex-con, Conrad Buckley, was found not-guilty by the jury. The judge said he thought this was the worst miscarriage of justice in all his years in the court system; telling the jurors either you are innately dishonest or you are complete morons. Court was adjourned.

A complete background check was conducted on each juror as directed from the District Attorney's Office; nothing came of it. None of the jurors were fixed, proven by the DA's investigation; the juror's didn't care, as Lieutenant Jones said. Friday comments to Lt. Jones, he thinks it stinks. The jurors took an apathetic view of the whole trial, as witness to their verdict. After all the hard evidence accrued for the case, the time it took getting it together to go to trial, it was an injustice perpetrated by the jury; Joe put it best. Word was the ex-con, named Buckley, left town for out East, then disappeared in a year's time.

It is February 1, of the new year, Captain Wisdom comes into the squad room, reporting another burglary just occurred, a printing company was robbed last night, all methods point to Conrad Buckley. Wisdom puts it plain to Joe and Ed, get him this time. Wisdom adds I don't know if that Greek with the lamp ever found an honest man, but get the guy.

Joe Friday, Ed Jacobs went out to the Cotter Printing Company spending the better part of the day going through the trail of possible evidence from the fourteen-thousand dollar safe burglary. Buckley entered through the skylight into the safe room; left no fingerprints. The Captain says to tail him starting with his favorite bar, where he was seen recently. Also, Buckley is now carrying a gun. The stakeouts began, at his home, tailing his friends, anything and anyone connected with him was followed.

Friday, Jacobs sit outside Comanchee's Bar for three nights, no sign of him; the fourth night at 8:10PM he showed, entering the bar. The officers waited. At 12:25 AM Buckley exits, accompanied by a blond woman on his arm, Buckley is walking unsteadily. The plate number is noted and ran; Nine Robert 702 is reported back to the men, car belonging to Mrs. Conrad Buckley, Beverly Hills. Friday, Jacobs trailed the Buckley's to the house; at 3 another group of detectives was dispatched to relieve Joe and Ed.

Conrad's movements were established by the end of that week as the Captain was charting on the squad room map. Wisdom assigned teams of men to trail Buckley's moves; on Tuesday he made his move and Friday, Jacobs were on him. Friday, Jacobs are joined by Wisdom as they sit in the car waiting on Buckley. The Captain said he left on foot, probably returning, since his car is in the driveway. A woman exits the house, gets into the car, the guys follow, she stops at an apartment house, later a man walks out with her, they get into the car, he drives. It is Buckley driving, says the Captain; Jacobs says this must be their hideout. The Captain instructs the officers to follow and shake them down, he will check the apartment, they are to meet later at the office. Friday, Jacobs find nothing in the house, the place is clean, after searching the suspect.

The Captain found two changes of clothes, hidden tools at the apartment. The unit is rented by Buckley under a false name. The only belongings are ones the captain found; tools were under a false bottom drawer. The plan is to watch both residences, the apartment is likely where Buckley would show after a job. There he would change, feeling he was safe from the law. Stakeouts prevailed at both locations, nothing out of the ordinary.

A wholesale grocer was burglarized of $7,500. Lt. Jones shows the Captain and the officers a chemical rubbed on a cloth that can't be detected by feel and can only seen under ultraviolet light as glowing when under the light only. Joe tries it to prove it works; the Lt. says it will work on Buckley. Officers Jones, Friday and Jacobs enter the apartment, dusting everywhere with the chemical, including clothes and tools.

The Captain gets the call of a safe job, two of them. An ultraviolet lamp is brought to the crime scene, the Lieutenant smiles as white hand prints appear on the burglarized safe. They all go the apartment, shining their light on his tools and clothes; they all contain white powder. The Lieutenant describes step by step Buckley's moves at the job in which he was acquitted, promising later, to be able to recount his moves on tonight's job. Conrad complains about his soiled clothes. Friday comments where he is going by the time he gets out they will be out of style. Buckley is arrested.

Suspect was tried and convicted on first-degree burglary, and due to his previous convictions, he was sentenced to life in prison. Conrad Buckley is now serving a life term in the State Penitentiary, San Quentin, CA.
